heading: Deaths
txt: Daniel Kinsey, American hurdler and scholar (b. 1902)

entities.title: Daniel Kinsey
entities.description: Daniel Chapin "Dan" Kinsey was an American hurdler and a scholar in physical education.

heading: Deaths
txt: G.I. Taylor, English mathematician and physicist (b. 1886)

entities.title: G.I. Taylor
entities.description: Sir Geoffrey Ingram Taylor OM FRS FRSE was an English physicist and mathematician, and a major figure in fluid dynamics and wave theory. His biographer and one-time student, George Batchelor, described him as "one of the most notable scientists of this century".

heading: Deaths
txt: Arthur Perdue, American businessman (b. 1885)

entities.title: Arthur Perdue
entities.description: Arthur W. Perdue was the founder of Perdue Farms along with his wife Pearl in 1920. The business was started in his backyard, and at the time only produced table eggs from chickens, but eventually grew into a $4.1 billion company.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Nepia, New Zealand rugby player and referee (b. 1905)

entities.description: George Nēpia was a New Zealand Māori rugby union and rugby league player. He is remembered as an exceptional full-back and one of the most famous Māori rugby players. He was inducted into the New Zealand Sports Hall of Fame in 1990. In 2004 he was selected as number 65 by the panel of the New Zealand's Top 100 History Makers television show. Nēpia was featured in a set of postage stamps from the N

heading: Deaths
txt: Billy Snedden, Australian lawyer and politician, 17th Attorney-General for Australia (b. 1926)

entities.description: Sir Billy Mackie Snedden, was an Australian politician who served as the leader of the Liberal Party from 1972 to 1975. He was also a cabinet minister from 1964 to 1972, and Speaker of the House of Representatives from 1976 to 1983.

entities.title: Attorney-General for Australia
entities.description: The Attorney-General of Australia is the First Law Officer of the Crown in right of the Commonwealth of Australia, chief law officer of the Commonwealth of Australia and a minister of state. The Attorney-General is usually a member of the Federal Cabinet, but need not be. Under the Constitution, they are appointed by the Governor-General on the advice of the Prime Minister, and serve at the Govern

heading: Deaths
txt: A. J. Ayer, English philosopher and academic (b. 1910)

entities.title: A. J. Ayer
entities.description: Sir Alfred Jules "Freddie" Ayer, usually cited as A. J. Ayer, was an English philosopher known for his promotion of logical positivism, particularly in his books Language, Truth, and Logic (1936) and The Problem of Knowledge (1956).

heading: Deaths
txt: Milton Subotsky, American-English screenwriter and producer (b. 1921)

entities.title: Milton Subotsky
entities.description: Milton Subotsky was an American film and television writer and producer. In 1964, he founded Amicus Productions with Max J. Rosenberg. Amicus means "friendship" in Latin. Together, they produced a number of low-budget science fiction and horror films in the United Kingdom.

heading: Deaths
txt: Albert R. Broccoli, American film producer (b. 1909)

entities.title: Albert R. Broccoli
entities.description: Albert Romolo Broccoli, nicknamed "Cubby", was an American film producer who made more than 40 motion pictures throughout his career. Most of the films were made in the United Kingdom and often filmed at Pinewood Studios. Co-founder of Danjaq, LLC and Eon Productions, Broccoli is most notable as the producer of many of the James Bond films. He and Harry Saltzman saw the films develop from relative

heading: Deaths
txt: Gilles Rocheleau, Canadian businessman and politician (b. 1935)

entities.title: Gilles Rocheleau
entities.description: Gilles Rocheleau was a member of the House of Commons of Canada from 1988 to 1993. He co-founded the Bloc Québécois with Lucien Bouchard in 1990.

heading: Deaths
txt: Georgios Papadopoulos, Greek colonel and politician, 169th Prime Minister of Greece (b. 1919)

entities.title: Georgios Papadopoulos
entities.description: Georgios Papadopoulos was a Greek dictator, the head of the military coup d'état that took place in Greece on 21 April 1967, and leader of the junta that ruled the country from 1967 to 1974. He held his dictatorial power until 1973, when he was himself overthrown by his co-conspirator Dimitrios Ioannidis.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Greece
entities.description: The prime minister of the Hellenic Republic, colloquially referred to as the prime minister of Greece, is the head of government of the Hellenic Republic and the leader of the Greek Cabinet. The incumbent prime minister is Kyriakos Mitsotakis, who took office on 8 July 2019.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pierre Pflimlin, French lawyer and politician, Prime Minister of France (b. 1907)

entities.title: Pierre Pflimlin
entities.description: Pierre Eugène Jean Pflimlin was a French Christian democratic politician who served as the Prime Minister of the Fourth Republic for a few weeks in 1958, before being replaced by Charles de Gaulle during the crisis of that year.

entities.title: Prime Minister of France
entities.description: The prime minister of the French Republic, sometimes shortened to premier, is the head of government of France. During the Third and Fourth Republics, the head of government was formally called president of the Council of Ministers, generally shortened to president of the Council. However, the post was usually called "prime minister" or "premier" in non-French sources. The prime minister is the ho

heading: Deaths
txt: Tove Jansson, Finnish author, illustrator, and painter (b. 1914)

entities.title: Tove Jansson
entities.description: Tove Marika Jansson was a Swedish-speaking Finnish author, novelist, painter, illustrator and comic strip author. Brought up by artistic parents, Jansson studied art from 1930 to 1938 in Stockholm, Helsinki and Paris. Her first solo art exhibition was in 1943. At the same time, she was writing short stories and articles for publication, as well as creating the graphics for book covers and other pu

heading: Deaths
txt: Jack Lemmon, American actor (b. 1925)

heading: Deaths
txt: Joan Sims, English actress (b. 1930)

heading: Deaths
txt: John Entwistle, English singer-songwriter, bass guitarist, and producer (b. 1944)

entities.title: John Entwistle
entities.description: John ‍Alec ‍Entwistle was an English musician and songwriter who was the bassist ‍for the rock band the Who. Nicknamed "The Ox" and "Thunderfingers", Entwistle's music career spanned over four decades. He was the band's only member with formal musical training and also provided backing and occasional lead vocals. Entwistle was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as a member of the Who in

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert L. J. Long, American admiral (b. 1920)

heading: Deaths
txt: David Newman, American director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1937)

entities.title: David Newman (screenwriter)
entities.description: David Newman was an American screenwriter. From the late 1960s through the early 1980s he frequently collaborated with Robert Benton. He was married to fellow writer Leslie Newman, with whom he had two children, until the time of his death. He died in 2003 of conditions from a stroke.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Patton IV, American general (b. 1923)

entities.title: George Patton IV
entities.description: George Smith Patton IV was a major general in the United States Army and the son of World War II General George S. Patton Jr. He served in the Korean War and the Vietnam War.

heading: Deaths
txt: Darrell Russell, American race car driver (b. 1968)

heading: Deaths
txt: Shelby Foote, American historian and author (b. 1917)

entities.title: Shelby Foote
entities.description: Shelby Dade Foote Jr. was an American writer, historian and journalist. Although he viewed himself primarily as a novelist, he is now best known for his The Civil War: A Narrative, a three-volume history of the American Civil War.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ray Holmes, English lieutenant and pilot (b. 1914)

heading: Deaths
txt: John T. Walton, American businessman, co-founded the Children's Scholarship Fund (b. 1946)

entities.title: Children's Scholarship Fund
entities.description: The Children's Scholarship Fund is a privately funded tuition assistance program in the United States. The fund provides scholarships enabling low-income children to attend private schools. More than 25,700 students in Kindergarten to 8th Grade receive the fund's scholarships. It was founded in 1998 by Theodore J. Forstmann and John T. Walton.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ángel Maturino Reséndiz, Mexican serial killer (b. 1959)

entities.title: Ángel Maturino Reséndiz
entities.description: Angel Maturino Reséndiz, also known as The Railroad Killer, was a Mexican-American itinerant serial killer suspected in as many as 23 murders across the United States and Mexico during the 1990s. Some also involved sexual assault. He had become known as "The Railroad Killer" as most of his crimes were committed near railroads where he had jumped off the trains he was using to travel about the coun

heading: Deaths
txt: William Hutt, Canadian actor (b. 1920)

entities.title: William Hutt (actor)
entities.description: William Ian DeWitt Hutt, was a Canadian actor of stage, television and film. Hutt's distinguished career spanned over fifty years and won him many accolades and awards. While his base throughout his career remained at the Stratford Festival in Stratford, Ontario, he appeared on the stage in London, New York and across Canada.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sam Manekshaw, Indian field marshal (b. 1914)

entities.title: Sam Manekshaw
entities.description: Field Marshal Sam Hormusji Framji Jamshedji Manekshaw,, widely known as Sam Manekshaw and Sam Bahadur, was the Chief of the Army Staff of the Indian Army during the Indo-Pakistani War of 1971, and the first Indian Army officer to be promoted to the rank of field marshal. His active military career spanned four decades and five wars, beginning with service in the British Indian Army in World War II

heading: Deaths
txt: Gale Storm, American actress (b. 1922)

entities.title: Gale Storm
entities.description: Josephine Owaissa Cottle, known professionally as Gale Storm, was an American actress and singer. After a film career from 1940 to 1952, she starred in two popular television programs of the 1950s, My Little Margie and The Gale Storm Show. Six of her songs were top ten hits. Storm's greatest recording success was a cover version of "I Hear You Knockin'," which hit #2 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart

heading: Deaths
txt: Corey Allen, American film and television actor, writer, director, and producer (b. 1934)

entities.title: Corey Allen
entities.description: Corey Allen was an American film and television director, writer, producer, and actor. He began his career as an actor but eventually became a television director. He may be best known for playing the character Buzz Gunderson in Nicholas Ray's Rebel Without a Cause (1955).

heading: Deaths
txt: Mike Doyle, English footballer (b. 1946)

entities.title: Mike Doyle (footballer)
entities.description: Michael Doyle was an English footballer, who spent the majority of his career with Manchester City and also played for Stoke City, Bolton Wanderers and Rochdale.

heading: Deaths
txt: Stan Cox, English runner (b. 1918)

entities.title: Stan Cox
entities.description: Stanley Ernest Walter Cox was a British athlete who competed in two Olympic games in 1948 and 1952. Born in Wood Green, England, he served with Royal Air Force in World War II before competing in the 10,000-metre event at the 1948 Summer Olympics. Unable to participate in the 1950 British Empire Games, he returned to the Olympics in 1952, although he did not complete his event, the marathon, due t

heading: Deaths
txt: Rosemary Dobson, Australian poet and illustrator (b. 1920)

heading: Deaths
txt: Stefano Borgonovo, Italian footballer (b. 1964)

entities.title: Stefano Borgonovo
entities.description: Stefano Borgonovo was an Italian footballer and manager, who played as a striker. An opportunistic striker, Borgonovo played for several Italian clubs throughout his career, and came to prominence while playing alongside Roberto Baggio with Fiorentina during the 1988–89 season, on loan from Milan. His prolific performances with Fiorentina earned him a permanent move to Milan, where he contributed

heading: Deaths
txt: Ian Scott, English-New Zealand painter (b. 1945)

heading: Deaths
txt: Edmond Blanchard, Canadian jurist and politician (b. 1954)

entities.title: Edmond Blanchard
entities.description: Edmond P. Blanchard was a Canadian jurist and politician.

heading: Deaths
txt: Allen Grossman, American poet, critic, and academic (b. 1932)

heading: Deaths
txt: Leslie Manigat, Haitian educator and politician, 43rd President of Haiti (b. 1930)

entities.title: President of Haiti
entities.description: The president of Haiti, officially called the president of the Republic of Haiti is the head of state of Haiti. Executive power in Haiti is divided between the president and the government headed by the Prime Minister of Haiti. The current president is Jovenel Moïse, who took office on February 7, 2017.

heading: Deaths
txt: Violet Milstead, Canadian World War II aviator and bush pilot (b. 1919)

entities.title: World War II
entities.description: World War II or the Second World War, often abbreviated as WWII or WW2, was a global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945. It involved the vast majority of the world's countries—including all the great powers—forming two opposing military alliances: the Allies and the Axis powers. In a state of total war, directly involving more than 100 million personnel from more than 30 countries, the major partic

entities.title: Bush pilot
entities.description: Bush flying refers to aircraft operations carried out in the bush. Bush flying involves operations in rough terrain where there are often no prepared landing strips or runways, frequently necessitating that bush planes be equipped with abnormally large tires, floats, skis or any other equipment necessary for unpaved runway operation. It is the only viable way of delivering people and supplies int

heading: Deaths
txt: Rachid Solh, Lebanese politician, 48th Prime Minister of Lebanon (b. 1926)

entities.title: Prime Minister of Lebanon
entities.description: The prime minister of Lebanon, officially the President of the Council of Ministers, is the head of government and the head of the Council of Ministers of Lebanon. The Prime Minister is appointed by the president of Lebanon, with no confirmation needed from the Parliament of Lebanon. By convention, the office holder is always a Sunni Muslim.

heading: Deaths
txt: Zvi Elpeleg, Polish-Israeli diplomat, author, and academic (b. 1926)

entities.title: Zvi Elpeleg
entities.description: Zvi Elpeleg was an academic, author, and a senior researcher at the Dayan Institute at Tel Aviv University. Born in Poland, Elpeleg served as a colonel in the Israeli army and later received an ambassadorial appointment.

heading: Deaths
txt: Knut Helle, Norwegian historian and professor (b. 1930)

heading: Deaths
txt: Chris Squire, English musician (bass guitarist), singer and songwriter, member of the rock band Yes (b. 1948)

entities.title: Yes (band)
entities.description: Yes are an English progressive rock band formed in London in 1968 by singer Jon Anderson, bassist Chris Squire, guitarist Peter Banks, keyboardist Tony Kaye, and drummer Bill Bruford. The band has undergone numerous formations throughout its history; nineteen musicians have been full-time members. Since June 2015, it has consisted of guitarist Steve Howe, drummer Alan White, keyboardist Geoff Down

heading: Deaths
txt: Bud Spencer, Italian swimmer, actor, and screenwriter (b. 1929)

entities.title: Bud Spencer
entities.description: Carlo Pedersoli, known professionally as Bud Spencer, was an Italian actor, professional swimmer and water polo player. He was known for action-comedy and Spaghetti Western roles with his long-time film partner Terence Hill. The duo "garnered world acclaim and attracted millions to theater seats". Spencer and Hill appeared in, produced and directed over 20 films together.

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter L. Berger, Austrian sociologist (b. 1929)

entities.title: Peter L. Berger
entities.description: Peter Ludwig Berger was an Austrian-born American sociologist and Protestant theologian. Berger became known for his work in the sociology of knowledge, the sociology of religion, study of modernization, and theoretical contributions to sociological theory.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joe Jackson, American manager, father of Michael Jackson and Janet Jackson (b. 1928)

entities.title: Joe Jackson (manager)
entities.description: Joseph Walter Jackson was an American talent manager and patriarch of the Jackson family of entertainers that includes his children Michael and Janet. He was inducted into the Rhythm and Blues Music Hall of Fame in 2014.

heading: Deaths
txt: Liz Jackson, Australian journalist and former barrister (b. 1951)
